speaker: DIANA
text_entry: That leads him to these places: were I his lady,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I would Poison that vile rascal.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which is he?

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: That jack-an-apes with scarfs: why is he melancholy?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Lose our drum! well.

speaker: MARIANA
text_entry: He's shrewdly vexed at something: look, he has spied us.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Marry, hang you!

speaker: MARIANA
text_entry: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier!

speaker: MARIANA
text_entry: Exeunt BERTRAM, PAROLLES, and army

speaker: Widow
text_entry: The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring you

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Where you shall host: of enjoin'd penitents

speaker: Widow
text_entry: There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Already at my house.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I humbly thank you:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Please it this matron and this gentle maid

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To eat with us to-night, the charge and thanking

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Shall be for me; and, to requite you further,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I will bestow some precepts of this virgin

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Worthy the note.

speaker: BOTH
text_entry: We'll take your offer kindly.

speaker: BOTH
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BOTH
text_entry: SCENE VI. Camp before Florence.

speaker: BOTH
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Nay, good my lord, put him to't; let him have his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: way.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: If your lordship find him not a hilding, hold me no

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: more in your respect.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Do you think I am so far deceived in him?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Believe it, my lord, in mine own direct knowledge,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: without any malice, but to speak of him as my

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: kinsman, he's a most notable coward, an infinite and

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: endless liar, an hourly promise-breaker, the owner

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: of no one good quality worthy your lordship's

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: entertainment.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: It were fit you knew him; lest, reposing too far in

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: his virtue, which he hath not, he might at some

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: great and trusty business in a main danger fail you.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I would I knew in what particular action to try him.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: None better than to let him fetch off his drum,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: which you hear him so confidently undertake to do.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I, with a troop of Florentines, will suddenly

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: surprise him; such I will have, whom I am sure he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: knows not from the enemy: we will bind and hoodwink

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: him so, that he shall suppose no other but that he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: is carried into the leaguer of the adversaries, when

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: we bring him to our own tents. Be but your lordship

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: present at his examination: if he do not, for the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: promise of his life and in the highest compulsion of

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: base fear, offer to betray you and deliver all the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: intelligence in his power against you, and that with

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: the divine forfeit of his soul upon oath, never

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: trust my judgment in any thing.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: O, for the love of laughter, let him fetch his drum;

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: he says he has a stratagem for't: when your

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: lordship sees the bottom of his success in't, and to

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: what metal this counterfeit lump of ore will be

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: melted, if you give him not John Drum's

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: entertainment, your inclining cannot be removed.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Here he comes.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: [Aside to BERTRAM]  O, for the love of laughter,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: hinder not the honour of his design: let him fetch

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: off his drum in any hand.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: How now, monsieur! this drum sticks sorely in your

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: disposition.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: A pox on't, let it go; 'tis but a drum.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: 'But a drum'! is't 'but a drum'? A drum so lost!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: There was excellent command,--to charge in with our

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: horse upon our own wings, and to rend our own soldiers!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That was not to be blamed in the command of the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: service: it was a disaster of war that Caesar

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: himself could not have prevented, if he had been

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: there to command.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Well, we cannot greatly condemn our success: some

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: dishonour we had in the loss of that drum; but it is

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: not to be recovered.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: It might have been recovered.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: It might; but it is not now.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: It is to be recovered: but that the merit of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: service is seldom attributed to the true and exact

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: performer, I would have that drum or another, or

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: 'hic jacet.'

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Why, if you have a stomach, to't, monsieur: if you

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: think your mystery in stratagem can bring this

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: instrument of honour again into his native quarter,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: be magnanimous in the enterprise and go on; I will

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: grace the attempt for a worthy exploit: if you

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: speed well in it, the duke shall both speak of it.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: and extend to you what further becomes his

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: greatness, even to the utmost syllable of your

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: worthiness.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: By the hand of a soldier, I will undertake it.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But you must not now slumber in it.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I'll about it this evening: and I will presently

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: pen down my dilemmas, encourage myself in my

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: certainty, put myself into my mortal preparation;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: and by midnight look to hear further from me.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: May I be bold to acquaint his grace you are gone about it?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I know not what the success will be, my lord; but

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the attempt I vow.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I know thou'rt valiant; and, to the possibility of

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: thy soldiership, will subscribe for thee. Farewell.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I love not many words.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: No more than a fish loves water. Is not this a

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: strange fellow, my lord, that so confidently seems

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: to undertake this business, which he knows is not to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: be done; damns himself to do and dares better be

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: damned than to do't?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You do not know him, my lord, as we do: certain it

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: is that he will steal himself into a man's favour and

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: for a week escape a great deal of discoveries; but

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: when you find him out, you have him ever after.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Why, do you think he will make no deed at all of

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: this that so seriously he does address himself unto?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: None in the world; but return with an invention and

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: clap upon you two or three probable lies: but we

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: have almost embossed him; you shall see his fall

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: to-night; for indeed he is not for your lordship's respect.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: We'll make you some sport with the fox ere we case

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: him. He was first smoked by the old lord Lafeu:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: when his disguise and he is parted, tell me what a

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: sprat you shall find him; which you shall see this

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: very night.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I must go look my twigs: he shall be caught.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Your brother he shall go along with me.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: As't please your lordship: I'll leave you.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Now will I lead you to the house, and show you

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: The lass I spoke of.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: But you say she's honest.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: That's all the fault: I spoke with her but once

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And found her wondrous cold; but I sent to her,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: By this same coxcomb that we have i' the wind,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Tokens and letters which she did re-send;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And this is all I have done. She's a fair creature:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Will you go see her?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: With all my heart, my lord.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: SCENE VII. Florence. The Widow's house.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter HELENA and Widow

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If you misdoubt me that I am not she,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I know not how I shall assure you further,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But I shall lose the grounds I work upon.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Though my estate be fallen, I was well born,

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Nothing acquainted with these businesses;

speaker: Widow
text_entry: And would not put my reputation now

speaker: Widow
text_entry: In any staining act.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor would I wish you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: First, give me trust, the count he is my husband,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And what to your sworn counsel I have spoken

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Is so from word to word; and then you cannot,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: By the good aid that I of you shall borrow,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Err in bestowing it.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: I should believe you:

speaker: Widow
text_entry: For you have show'd me that which well approves

speaker: Widow
text_entry: You're great in fortune.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Take this purse of gold,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And let me buy your friendly help thus far,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which I will over-pay and pay again

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When I have found it. The count he wooes your daughter,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Lays down his wanton siege before her beauty,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Resolved to carry her: let her in fine consent,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: As we'll direct her how 'tis best to bear it.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Now his important blood will nought deny

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That she'll demand: a ring the county wears,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That downward hath succeeded in his house

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: From son to son, some four or five descents

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Since the first father wore it: this ring he holds

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: In most rich choice; yet in his idle fire,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To buy his will, it would not seem too dear,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Howe'er repented after.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Now I see

speaker: Widow
text_entry: The bottom of your purpose.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: You see it lawful, then: it is no more,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But that your daughter, ere she seems as won,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Desires this ring; appoints him an encounter;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: In fine, delivers me to fill the time,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Herself most chastely absent: after this,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To marry her, I'll add three thousand crowns

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To what is passed already.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: I have yielded:

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Instruct my daughter how she shall persever,

speaker: Widow
text_entry: That time and place with this deceit so lawful

speaker: Widow
text_entry: May prove coherent. Every night he comes

speaker: Widow
text_entry: With musics of all sorts and songs composed

speaker: Widow
text_entry: To her unworthiness: it nothing steads us

speaker: Widow
text_entry: To chide him from our eaves; for he persists

speaker: Widow
text_entry: As if his life lay on't.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Why then to-night

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Let us assay our plot; which, if it speed,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Is wicked meaning in a lawful deed

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And lawful meaning in a lawful act,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Where both not sin, and yet a sinful fact:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But let's about it.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: SCENE I. Without the Florentine camp.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter Second French Lord, with five or six other Soldiers in ambush

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He can come no other way but by this hedge-corner.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: When you sally upon him, speak what terrible

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: language you will: though you understand it not

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: yourselves, no matter; for we must not seem to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: understand him, unless some one among us whom we

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: must produce for an interpreter.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Good captain, let me be the interpreter.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Art not acquainted with him? knows he not thy voice?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: No, sir, I warrant you.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: But what linsey-woolsey hast thou to speak to us again?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: E'en such as you speak to me.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He must think us some band of strangers i' the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: adversary's entertainment. Now he hath a smack of

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: all neighbouring languages; therefore we must every

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: one be a man of his own fancy, not to know what we

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: speak one to another; so we seem to know, is to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: know straight our purpose: choughs' language,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: gabble enough, and good enough. As for you,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: interpreter, you must seem very politic. But couch,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: ho! here he comes, to beguile two hours in a sleep,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: and then to return and swear the lies he forges.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ten o'clock: within these three hours 'twill be

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: time enough to go home. What shall I say I have

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: done? It must be a very plausive invention that

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: carries it: they begin to smoke me; and disgraces

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: have of late knocked too often at my door. I find

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: my tongue is too foolhardy; but my heart hath the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fear of Mars before it and of his creatures, not

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: daring the reports of my tongue.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: This is the first truth that e'er thine own tongue

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: was guilty of.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: What the devil should move me to undertake the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: recovery of this drum, being not ignorant of the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: impossibility, and knowing I had no such purpose? I

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: must give myself some hurts, and say I got them in

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: exploit: yet slight ones will not carry it; they

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: will say, 'Came you off with so little?' and great

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ones I dare not give. Wherefore, what's the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: instance? Tongue, I must put you into a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: butter-woman's mouth and buy myself another of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Bajazet's mule, if you prattle me into these perils.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Is it possible he should know what he is, and be

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: that he is?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I would the cutting of my garments would serve the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: turn, or the breaking of my Spanish sword.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We cannot afford you so.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Or the baring of my beard; and to say it was in

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: stratagem.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: 'Twould not do.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Or to drown my clothes, and say I was stripped.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Hardly serve.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Though I swore I leaped from the window of the citadel.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: How deep?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Thirty fathom.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Three great oaths would scarce make that be believed.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I would I had any drum of the enemy's: I would swear

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I recovered it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: You shall hear one anon.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: A drum now of the enemy's,--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Alarum within

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Throca movousus, cargo, cargo, cargo.

speaker: All
text_entry: Cargo, cargo, cargo, villiando par corbo, cargo.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O, ransom, ransom! do not hide mine eyes.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: They seize and blindfold him

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Boskos thromuldo boskos.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I know you are the Muskos' regiment:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: And I shall lose my life for want of language;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: If there be here German, or Dane, low Dutch,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Italian, or French, let him speak to me; I'll

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Discover that which shall undo the Florentine.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Boskos vauvado: I understand thee, and can speak

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: thy tongue. Kerely bonto, sir, betake thee to thy

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: faith, for seventeen poniards are at thy bosom.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O!

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: O, pray, pray, pray! Manka revania dulche.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Oscorbidulchos volivorco.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: The general is content to spare thee yet;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: And, hoodwink'd as thou art, will lead thee on

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: To gather from thee: haply thou mayst inform

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Something to save thy life.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O, let me live!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: And all the secrets of our camp I'll show,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Their force, their purposes; nay, I'll speak that

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Which you will wonder at.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: But wilt thou faithfully?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: If I do not, damn me.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Acordo linta.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Come on; thou art granted space.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Exit, with PAROLLES guarded. A short alarum within

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Go, tell the Count Rousillon, and my brother,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We have caught the woodcock, and will keep him muffled

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Till we do hear from them.

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: Captain, I will.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: A' will betray us all unto ourselves:

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Inform on that.

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: So I will, sir.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Till then I'll keep him dark and safely lock'd.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: SCENE II. Florence. The Widow's house.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM and DIANA

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: They told me that your name was Fontibell.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: No, my good lord, Diana.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Titled goddess;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And worth it, with addition! But, fair soul,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: In your fine frame hath love no quality?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: If quick fire of youth light not your mind,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: You are no maiden, but a monument:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: When you are dead, you should be such a one

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: As you are now, for you are cold and stem;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And now you should be as your mother was

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: When your sweet self was got.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: She then was honest.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: So should you be.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: No:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My mother did but duty; such, my lord,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: As you owe to your wife.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: No more o' that;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I prithee, do not strive against my vows:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I was compell'd to her; but I love thee

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: By love's own sweet constraint, and will for ever

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Do thee all rights of service.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Ay, so you serve us

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Till we serve you; but when you have our roses,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: You barely leave our thorns to prick ourselves

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And mock us with our bareness.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: How have I sworn!

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: 'Tis not the many oaths that makes the truth,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: But the plain single vow that is vow'd true.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: What is not holy, that we swear not by,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: But take the High'st to witness: then, pray you, tell me,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: If I should swear by God's great attributes,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I loved you dearly, would you believe my oaths,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When I did love you ill? This has no holding,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: To swear by him whom I protest to love,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: That I will work against him: therefore your oaths

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Are words and poor conditions, but unseal'd,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: At least in my opinion.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Change it, change it;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Be not so holy-cruel: love is holy;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And my integrity ne'er knew the crafts

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: That you do charge men with. Stand no more off,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But give thyself unto my sick desires,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Who then recover: say thou art mine, and ever

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: My love as it begins shall so persever.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I see that men make ropes in such a scarre

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: That we'll forsake ourselves. Give me that ring.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I'll lend it thee, my dear; but have no power

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: To give it from me.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Will you not, my lord?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: It is an honour 'longing to our house,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Bequeathed down from many ancestors;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: In me to lose.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Mine honour's such a ring:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My chastity's the jewel of our house,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Bequeathed down from many ancestors;

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Which were the greatest obloquy i' the world

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: In me to lose: thus your own proper wisdom

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Brings in the champion Honour on my part,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Against your vain assault.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Here, take my ring:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: My house, mine honour, yea, my life, be thine,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: And I'll be bid by thee.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When midnight comes, knock at my chamber-window:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: I'll order take my mother shall not hear.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Now will I charge you in the band of truth,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When you have conquer'd my yet maiden bed,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Remain there but an hour, nor speak to me:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My reasons are most strong; and you shall know them

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When back again this ring shall be deliver'd:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: And on your finger in the night I'll put

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Another ring, that what in time proceeds

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: May token to the future our past deeds.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Adieu, till then; then, fail not. You have won

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: A wife of me, though there my hope be done.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A heaven on earth I have won by wooing thee.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: For which live long to thank both heaven and me!

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: You may so in the end.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: My mother told me just how he would woo,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: As if she sat in 's heart; she says all men

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Have the like oaths: he had sworn to marry me

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When his wife's dead; therefore I'll lie with him

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: When I am buried. Since Frenchmen are so braid,

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Marry that will, I live and die a maid:

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Only in this disguise I think't no sin

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: To cozen him that would unjustly win.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: SCENE III. The Florentine camp.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Enter the two French Lords and some two or three Soldiers

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You have not given him his mother's letter?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I have delivered it an hour since: there is

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: something in't that stings his nature; for on the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: reading it he changed almost into another man.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He has much worthy blame laid upon him for shaking

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: off so good a wife and so sweet a lady.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Especially he hath incurred the everlasting

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: displeasure of the king, who had even tuned his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: bounty to sing happiness to him. I will tell you a

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: thing, but you shall let it dwell darkly with you.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: When you have spoken it, 'tis dead, and I am the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: grave of it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He hath perverted a young gentlewoman here in

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Florence, of a most chaste renown; and this night he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: fleshes his will in the spoil of her honour: he hath

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: given her his monumental ring, and thinks himself

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: made in the unchaste composition.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Now, God delay our rebellion! as we are ourselves,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: what things are we!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Merely our own traitors. And as in the common course

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: of all treasons, we still see them reveal

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: themselves, till they attain to their abhorred ends,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: so he that in this action contrives against his own

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: nobility, in his proper stream o'erflows himself.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Is it not meant damnable in us, to be trumpeters of

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: our unlawful intents? We shall not then have his

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: company to-night?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Not till after midnight; for he is dieted to his hour.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That approaches apace; I would gladly have him see

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: his company anatomized, that he might take a measure

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: of his own judgments, wherein so curiously he had

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: set this counterfeit.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: We will not meddle with him till he come; for his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: presence must be the whip of the other.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: In the mean time, what hear you of these wars?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I hear there is an overture of peace.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Nay, I assure you, a peace concluded.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: What will Count Rousillon do then? will he travel

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: higher, or return again into France?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I perceive, by this demand, you are not altogether

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: of his council.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Let it be forbid, sir; so should I be a great deal

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: of his act.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Sir, his wife some two months since fled from his

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: house: her pretence is a pilgrimage to Saint Jaques

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: le Grand; which holy undertaking with most austere

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: sanctimony she accomplished; and, there residing the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: tenderness of her nature became as a prey to her

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: grief; in fine, made a groan of her last breath, and

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: now she sings in heaven.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: How is this justified?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The stronger part of it by her own letters, which

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: makes her story true, even to the point of her

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: death: her death itself, which could not be her

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: office to say is come, was faithfully confirmed by

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: the rector of the place.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Hath the count all this intelligence?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Ay, and the particular confirmations, point from

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: point, so to the full arming of the verity.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I am heartily sorry that he'll be glad of this.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: How mightily sometimes we make us comforts of our losses!

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: And how mightily some other times we drown our gain

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: in tears! The great dignity that his valour hath

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: here acquired for him shall at home be encountered

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: with a shame as ample.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The web of our life is of a mingled yarn, good and

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: ill together: our virtues would be proud, if our

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: faults whipped them not; and our crimes would

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: despair, if they were not cherished by our virtues.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: How now! where's your master?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He met the duke in the street, sir, of whom he hath

speaker: Servant
text_entry: taken a solemn leave: his lordship will next

speaker: Servant
text_entry: morning for France. The duke hath offered him

speaker: Servant
text_entry: letters of commendations to the king.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: They shall be no more than needful there, if they

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: were more than they can commend.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: They cannot be too sweet for the king's tartness.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Here's his lordship now.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Enter BERTRAM

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: How now, my lord! is't not after midnight?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I have to-night dispatched sixteen businesses, a

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: month's length a-piece, by an abstract of success:

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I have congied with the duke, done my adieu with his

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: nearest; buried a wife, mourned for her; writ to my

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: lady mother I am returning; entertained my convoy;

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: and between these main parcels of dispatch effected

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: many nicer needs; the last was the greatest, but

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: that I have not ended yet.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: If the business be of any difficulty, and this

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: morning your departure hence, it requires haste of

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: your lordship.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I mean, the business is not ended, as fearing to

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: hear of it hereafter. But shall we have this

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: dialogue between the fool and the soldier? Come,

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: bring forth this counterfeit module, he has deceived

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: me, like a double-meaning prophesier.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Bring him forth: has sat i' the stocks all night,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: poor gallant knave.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: No matter: his heels have deserved it, in usurping

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: his spurs so long. How does he carry himself?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I have told your lordship already, the stocks carry

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: him. But to answer you as you would be understood;

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: he weeps like a wench that had shed her milk: he

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: hath confessed himself to Morgan, whom he supposes

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: to be a friar, from the time of his remembrance to

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: this very instant disaster of his setting i' the

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: stocks: and what think you he hath confessed?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Nothing of me, has a'?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: His confession is taken, and it shall be read to his

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: face: if your lordship be in't, as I believe you

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: are, you must have the patience to hear it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Enter PAROLLES guarded, and First Soldier

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A plague upon him! muffled! he can say nothing of

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: me: hush, hush!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hoodman comes! Portotartarosa

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: He calls for the tortures: what will you say

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: without 'em?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I will confess what I know without constraint: if

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ye pinch me like a pasty, I can say no more.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Bosko chimurcho.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Boblibindo chicurmurco.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: You are a merciful general. Our general bids you

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: answer to what I shall ask you out of a note.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: And truly, as I hope to live.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  'First demand of him how many horse the

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: duke is strong.' What say you to that?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Five or six thousand; but very weak and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: unserviceable: the troops are all scattered, and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the commanders very poor rogues, upon my reputation

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: and credit and as I hope to live.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Shall I set down your answer so?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Do: I'll take the sacrament on't, how and which way you will.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: All's one to him. What a past-saving slave is this!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: You're deceived, my lord: this is Monsieur

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Parolles, the gallant militarist,--that was his own

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: phrase,--that had the whole theoric of war in the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: knot of his scarf, and the practise in the chape of

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: his dagger.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I will never trust a man again for keeping his sword

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: clean. nor believe he can have every thing in him

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: by wearing his apparel neatly.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, that's set down.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Five or six thousand horse, I said,-- I will say

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: true,--or thereabouts, set down, for I'll speak truth.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He's very near the truth in this.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: But I con him no thanks for't, in the nature he

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: delivers it.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Poor rogues, I pray you, say.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, that's set down.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I humbly thank you, sir: a truth's a truth, the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: rogues are marvellous poor.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  'Demand of him, of what strength they are

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: a-foot.' What say you to that?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: By my troth, sir, if I were to live this present

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: hour, I will tell true. Let me see: Spurio, a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: hundred and fifty; Sebastian, so many; Corambus, so

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: many; Jaques, so many; Guiltian, Cosmo, Lodowick,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: and Gratii, two hundred and fifty each; mine own

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: company, Chitopher, Vaumond, Bentii, two hundred and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fifty each: so that the muster-file, rotten and

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: sound, upon my life, amounts not to fifteen thousand

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: poll; half of the which dare not shake snow from off

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: their cassocks, lest they shake themselves to pieces.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: What shall be done to him?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Nothing, but let him have thanks. Demand of him my

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: condition, and what credit I have with the duke.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, that's set down.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Reads

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: 'You shall demand of him, whether one Captain Dumain

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: be i' the camp, a Frenchman; what his reputation is

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: with the duke; what his valour, honesty, and

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: expertness in wars; or whether he thinks it were not

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: possible, with well-weighing sums of gold, to

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: corrupt him to revolt.' What say you to this? what

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: do you know of it?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I beseech you, let me answer to the particular of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the inter'gatories: demand them singly.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Do you know this Captain Dumain?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I know him: a' was a botcher's 'prentice in Paris,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: from whence he was whipped for getting the shrieve's

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fool with child,--a dumb innocent, that could not

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: say him nay.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Nay, by your leave, hold your hands; though I know

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: his brains are forfeit to the next tile that falls.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Well, is this captain in the duke of Florence's camp?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Upon my knowledge, he is, and lousy.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Nay look not so upon me; we shall hear of your

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: lordship anon.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: What is his reputation with the duke?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: The duke knows him for no other but a poor officer

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: of mine; and writ to me this other day to turn him

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: out o' the band: I think I have his letter in my pocket.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Marry, we'll search.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: In good sadness, I do not know; either it is there,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: or it is upon a file with the duke's other letters

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: in my tent.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Here 'tis; here's a paper: shall I read it to you?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I do not know if it be it or no.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Our interpreter does it well.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Excellently.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  'Dian, the count's a fool, and full of gold,'--

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: That is not the duke's letter, sir; that is an

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: advertisement to a proper maid in Florence, one

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Diana, to take heed of the allurement of one Count

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Rousillon, a foolish idle boy, but for all that very

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: ruttish: I pray you, sir, put it up again.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Nay, I'll read it first, by your favour.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My meaning in't, I protest, was very honest in the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: behalf of the maid; for I knew the young count to be

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: a dangerous and lascivious boy, who is a whale to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: virginity and devours up all the fry it finds.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Damnable both-sides rogue!

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: [Reads]  'When he swears oaths, bid him drop gold, and take it;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: After he scores, he never pays the score:

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Half won is match well made; match, and well make it;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: He ne'er pays after-debts, take it before;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: And say a soldier, Dian, told thee this,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Men are to mell with, boys are not to kiss:

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: For count of this, the count's a fool, I know it,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Who pays before, but not when he does owe it.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Thine, as he vowed to thee in thine ear,

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: PAROLLES.'

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: He shall be whipped through the army with this rhyme

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: in's forehead.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: This is your devoted friend, sir, the manifold

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: linguist and the armipotent soldier.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: I could endure any thing before but a cat, and now

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: he's a cat to me.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: I perceive, sir, by the general's looks, we shall be

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: fain to hang you.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My life, sir, in any case: not that I am afraid to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: die; but that, my offences being many, I would

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: repent out the remainder of nature: let me live,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: sir, in a dungeon, i' the stocks, or any where, so I may live.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: We'll see what may be done, so you confess freely;

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: therefore, once more to this Captain Dumain: you

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: have answered to his reputation with the duke and to

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: his valour: what is his honesty?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: He will steal, sir, an egg out of a cloister: for

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: rapes and ravishments he parallels Nessus: he

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: professes not keeping of oaths; in breaking 'em he

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: is stronger than Hercules: he will lie, sir, with

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: such volubility, that you would think truth were a

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: fool: drunkenness is his best virtue, for he will

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: be swine-drunk; and in his sleep he does little

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: harm, save to his bed-clothes about him; but they

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: know his conditions and lay him in straw. I have but

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: little more to say, sir, of his honesty: he has

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: every thing that an honest man should not have; what

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: an honest man should have, he has nothing.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I begin to love him for this.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: For this description of thine honesty? A pox upon

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: him for me, he's more and more a cat.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: What say you to his expertness in war?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Faith, sir, he has led the drum before the English

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: tragedians; to belie him, I will not, and more of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: his soldiership I know not; except, in that country

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: he had the honour to be the officer at a place there

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: called Mile-end, to instruct for the doubling of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: files: I would do the man what honour I can, but of

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: this I am not certain.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He hath out-villained villany so far, that the

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: rarity redeems him.

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: A pox on him, he's a cat still.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: His qualities being at this poor price, I need not

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: to ask you if gold will corrupt him to revolt.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Sir, for a quart d'ecu he will sell the fee-simple

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: of his salvation, the inheritance of it; and cut the

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: entail from all remainders, and a perpetual

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: succession for it perpetually.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: What's his brother, the other Captain Dumain?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Why does be ask him of me?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: What's he?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: E'en a crow o' the same nest; not altogether so

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: great as the first in goodness, but greater a great

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: deal in evil: he excels his brother for a coward,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: yet his brother is reputed one of the best that is:

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: in a retreat he outruns any lackey; marry, in coming

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: on he has the cramp.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: If your life be saved, will you undertake to betray

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: the Florentine?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Ay, and the captain of his horse, Count Rousillon.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: I'll whisper with the general, and know his pleasure.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: [Aside]  I'll no more drumming; a plague of all

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: drums! Only to seem to deserve well, and to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: beguile the supposition of that lascivious young boy

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: the count, have I run into this danger. Yet who

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: would have suspected an ambush where I was taken?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: There is no remedy, sir, but you must die: the

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: general says, you that have so traitorously

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: discovered the secrets of your army and made such

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: pestiferous reports of men very nobly held, can

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: serve the world for no honest use; therefore you

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: must die. Come, headsman, off with his head.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O Lord, sir, let me live, or let me see my death!

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That shall you, and take your leave of all your friends.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Unblinding him

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: So, look about you: know you any here?

speaker: BERTRAM
text_entry: Good morrow, noble captain.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: God bless you, Captain Parolles.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: God save you, noble captain.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Captain, what greeting will you to my Lord Lafeu?

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: I am for France.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Good captain, will you give me a copy of the sonnet

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: you writ to Diana in behalf of the Count Rousillon?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: an I were not a very coward, I'ld compel it of you:

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: but fare you well.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt BERTRAM and Lords

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: You are undone, captain, all but your scarf; that

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: has a knot on't yet

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Who cannot be crushed with a plot?

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: If you could find out a country where but women were

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: that had received so much shame, you might begin an

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: impudent nation. Fare ye well, sir; I am for France

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: too: we shall speak of you there.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Exit with Soldiers

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Yet am I thankful: if my heart were great,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: 'Twould burst at this. Captain I'll be no more;

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: But I will eat and drink, and sleep as soft

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: As captain shall: simply the thing I am

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Shall make me live. Who knows himself a braggart,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Let him fear this, for it will come to pass

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: that every braggart shall be found an ass.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Rust, sword? cool, blushes! and, Parolles, live

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Safest in shame! being fool'd, by foolery thrive!

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: There's place and means for every man alive.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I'll after them.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: SCENE IV. Florence. The Widow's house.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That you may well perceive I have not wrong'd you,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: One of the greatest in the Christian world

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Shall be my surety; 'fore whose throne 'tis needful,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ere I can perfect mine intents, to kneel:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Time was, I did him a desired office,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Dear almost as his life; which gratitude

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Through flinty Tartar's bosom would peep forth,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And answer, thanks: I duly am inform'd

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: His grace is at Marseilles; to which place

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We have convenient convoy. You must know

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I am supposed dead: the army breaking,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: My husband hies him home; where, heaven aiding,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And by the leave of my good lord the king,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: We'll be before our welcome.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Gentle madam,

speaker: Widow
text_entry: You never had a servant to whose trust

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Your business was more welcome.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Nor you, mistress,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Ever a friend whose thoughts more truly labour

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To recompense your love: doubt not but heaven

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Hath brought me up to be your daughter's dower,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: As it hath fated her to be my motive

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And helper to a husband. But, O strange men!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That can such sweet use make of what they hate,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When saucy trusting of the cozen'd thoughts

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Defiles the pitchy night: so lust doth play

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: With what it loathes for that which is away.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But more of this hereafter. You, Diana,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Under my poor instructions yet must suffer

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Something in my behalf.

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Let death and honesty

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Go with your impositions, I am yours

speaker: DIANA
text_entry: Upon your will to suffer.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Yet, I pray you:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But with the word the time will bring on summer,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: When briers shall have leaves as well as thorns,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And be as sweet as sharp. We must away;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Our wagon is prepared, and time revives us:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: All's well that ends well; still the fine's the crown;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Whate'er the course, the end is the renown.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: SCENE V. Rousillon. The COUNT's palace.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter COUNTESS, LAFEU, and Clown

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: No, no, no, your son was misled with a snipt-taffeta

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: fellow there, whose villanous saffron would have

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: made all the unbaked and doughy youth of a nation in

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: his colour: your daughter-in-law had been alive at

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: this hour, and your son here at home, more advanced

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: by the king than by that red-tailed humble-bee I speak of.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: I would I had not known him; it was the death of the

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: most virtuous gentlewoman that ever nature had

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: praise for creating. If she had partaken of my

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: flesh, and cost me the dearest groans of a mother, I

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: could not have owed her a more rooted love.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: 'Twas a good lady, 'twas a good lady: we may pick a

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thousand salads ere we light on such another herb.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Indeed, sir, she was the sweet marjoram of the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: salad, or rather, the herb of grace.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: They are not herbs, you knave; they are nose-herbs.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I am no great Nebuchadnezzar, sir; I have not much

speaker: Clown
text_entry: skill in grass.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Whether dost thou profess thyself, a knave or a fool?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: A fool, sir, at a woman's service, and a knave at a man's.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Your distinction?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I would cozen the man of his wife and do his service.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: So you were a knave at his service, indeed.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: And I would give his wife my bauble, sir, to do her service.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I will subscribe for thee, thou art both knave and fool.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: At your service.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: No, no, no.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Why, sir, if I cannot serve you, I can serve as

speaker: Clown
text_entry: great a prince as you are.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Who's that? a Frenchman?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Faith, sir, a' has an English name; but his fisnomy

speaker: Clown
text_entry: is more hotter in France than there.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: What prince is that?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: The black prince, sir; alias, the prince of

speaker: Clown
text_entry: darkness; alias, the devil.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Hold thee, there's my purse: I give thee not this

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: to suggest thee from thy master thou talkest of;

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: serve him still.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I am a woodland fellow, sir, that always loved a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: great fire; and the master I speak of ever keeps a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: good fire. But, sure, he is the prince of the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: world; let his nobility remain in's court. I am for

speaker: Clown
text_entry: the house with the narrow gate, which I take to be

speaker: Clown
text_entry: too little for pomp to enter: some that humble

speaker: Clown
text_entry: themselves may; but the many will be too chill and

speaker: Clown
text_entry: tender, and they'll be for the flowery way that

speaker: Clown
text_entry: leads to the broad gate and the great fire.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Go thy ways, I begin to be aweary of thee; and I

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: tell thee so before, because I would not fall out

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: with thee. Go thy ways: let my horses be well

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: looked to, without any tricks.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: If I put any tricks upon 'em, sir, they shall be

speaker: Clown
text_entry: jades' tricks; which are their own right by the law of nature.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: A shrewd knave and an unhappy.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: So he is. My lord that's gone made himself much

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: sport out of him: by his authority he remains here,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: which he thinks is a patent for his sauciness; and,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: indeed, he has no pace, but runs where he will.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I like him well; 'tis not amiss. And I was about to

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: tell you, since I heard of the good lady's death and

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: that my lord your son was upon his return home, I

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: moved the king my master to speak in the behalf of

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: my daughter; which, in the minority of them both,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: his majesty, out of a self-gracious remembrance, did

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: first propose: his highness hath promised me to do

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: it: and, to stop up the displeasure he hath

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: conceived against your son, there is no fitter

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: matter. How does your ladyship like it?

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: With very much content, my lord; and I wish it

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: happily effected.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: His highness comes post from Marseilles, of as able

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: body as when he numbered thirty: he will be here

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: to-morrow, or I am deceived by him that in such

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: intelligence hath seldom failed.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: It rejoices me, that I hope I shall see him ere I

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: die. I have letters that my son will be here

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: to-night: I shall beseech your lordship to remain

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: with me till they meet together.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Madam, I was thinking with what manners I might

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: safely be admitted.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: You need but plead your honourable privilege.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Lady, of that I have made a bold charter; but I

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thank my God it holds yet.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Re-enter Clown

speaker: Clown
text_entry: O madam, yonder's my lord your son with a patch of

speaker: Clown
text_entry: velvet on's face: whether there be a scar under't

speaker: Clown
text_entry: or no, the velvet knows; but 'tis a goodly patch of

speaker: Clown
text_entry: velvet: his left cheek is a cheek of two pile and a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: half, but his right cheek is worn bare.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: A scar nobly got, or a noble scar, is a good livery

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: of honour; so belike is that.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: But it is your carbonadoed face.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Let us go see your son, I pray you: I long to talk

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: with the young noble soldier.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Faith there's a dozen of 'em, with delicate fine

speaker: Clown
text_entry: hats and most courteous feathers, which bow the head

speaker: Clown
text_entry: and nod at every man.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Clown
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: Clown
text_entry: SCENE I. Marseilles. A street.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Enter HELENA, Widow, and DIANA, with two Attendants

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But this exceeding posting day and night

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Must wear your spirits low; we cannot help it:

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But since you have made the days and nights as one,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To wear your gentle limbs in my affairs,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Be bold you do so grow in my requital

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: As nothing can unroot you. In happy time;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter a Gentleman

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: This man may help me to his majesty's ear,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: If he would spend his power. God save you, sir.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: And you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Sir, I have seen you in the court of France.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: I have been sometimes there.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I do presume, sir, that you are not fallen

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: From the report that goes upon your goodness;

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: An therefore, goaded with most sharp occasions,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which lay nice manners by, I put you to

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: The use of your own virtues, for the which

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I shall continue thankful.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: What's your will?

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: That it will please you

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To give this poor petition to the king,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And aid me with that store of power you have

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: To come into his presence.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: The king's not here.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Not here, sir!

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Not, indeed:

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: He hence removed last night and with more haste

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Than is his use.

speaker: Widow
text_entry: Lord, how we lose our pains!

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL yet,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Though time seem so adverse and means unfit.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I do beseech you, whither is he gone?

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Marry, as I take it, to Rousillon;

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: Whither I am going.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I do beseech you, sir,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Since you are like to see the king before me,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Commend the paper to his gracious hand,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Which I presume shall render you no blame

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: But rather make you thank your pains for it.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: I will come after you with what good speed

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Our means will make us means.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: This I'll do for you.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: And you shall find yourself to be well thank'd,

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Whate'er falls more. We must to horse again.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Go, go, provide.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: SCENE II. Rousillon. Before the COUNT's palace.

speaker: HELENA
text_entry: Enter Clown, and PAROLLES, following

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Good Monsieur Lavache, give my Lord Lafeu this

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: letter: I have ere now, sir, been better known to

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: you, when I have held familiarity with fresher

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: clothes; but I am now, sir, muddied in fortune's

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: displeasure.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Truly, fortune's displeasure is but sluttish, if it

speaker: Clown
text_entry: smell so strongly as thou speakest of: I will

speaker: Clown
text_entry: henceforth eat no fish of fortune's buttering.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Prithee, allow the wind.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir; I spake

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: but by a metaphor.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my

speaker: Clown
text_entry: nose; or against any man's metaphor. Prithee, get

speaker: Clown
text_entry: thee further.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Foh! prithee, stand away: a paper from fortune's

speaker: Clown
text_entry: close-stool to give to a nobleman! Look, here he

speaker: Clown
text_entry: comes himself.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Enter LAFEU

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Here is a purr of fortune's, sir, or of fortune's

speaker: Clown
text_entry: cat,--but not a musk-cat,--that has fallen into the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and, as he

speaker: Clown
text_entry: says, is muddied withal: pray you, sir, use the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: carp as you may; for he looks like a poor, decayed,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his

speaker: Clown
text_entry: distress in my similes of comfort and leave him to

speaker: Clown
text_entry: your lordship.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My lord, I am a man whom fortune hath cruelly

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: scratched.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: And what would you have me to do? 'Tis too late to

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: pare her nails now. Wherein have you played the

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: knave with fortune, that she should scratch you, who

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: of herself is a good lady and would not have knaves

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thrive long under her? There's a quart d'ecu for

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: you: let the justices make you and fortune friends:

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: I am for other business.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: You beg a single penny more: come, you shall ha't;

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: save your word.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: You beg more than 'word,' then. Cox my passion!

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: give me your hand. How does your drum?

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Was I, in sooth? and I was the first that lost thee.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace,

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: for you did bring me out.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at once

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: both the office of God and the devil? One brings

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: thee in grace and the other brings thee out.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Trumpets sound

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: The king's coming; I know by his trumpets. Sirrah,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: inquire further after me; I had talk of you last

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: night: though you are a fool and a knave, you shall

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: eat; go to, follow.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: I praise God for you.

speaker: PAROLLES
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: PAROLLES

speaker: PAROLLES

speaker: KING
text_entry: We lost a jewel of her; and our esteem

speaker: KING
text_entry: Was made much poorer by it: but your son,

speaker: KING
text_entry: As mad in folly, lack'd the sense to know

speaker: KING
text_entry: Her estimation home.

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: 'Tis past, my liege;

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: And I beseech your majesty to make it

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: Natural rebellion, done i' the blaze of youth;

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: When oil and fire, too strong for reason's force,

speaker: COUNTESS
text_entry: O'erbears it and burns on.

speaker: KING
text_entry: My honour'd lady,

speaker: KING
text_entry: I have forgiven and forgotten all;

speaker: KING
text_entry: Though my revenges were high bent upon him,

speaker: KING
text_entry: And watch'd the time to shoot.

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: This I must say,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: But first I beg my pardon, the young lord

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Did to his majesty, his mother and his lady

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Offence of mighty note; but to himself

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: The greatest wrong of all. He lost a wife

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Whose beauty did astonish the survey

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Of richest eyes, whose words all ears took captive,

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Whose dear perfection hearts that scorn'd to serve

speaker: LAFEU
text_entry: Humbly call'd mistress.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Praising what is lost

speaker: KING
text_entry: Makes the remembrance dear. Well, call him hither;

speaker: KING
text_entry: We are reconciled, and the first view shall kill

speaker: KING
text_entry: All repetition: let him not ask our pardon;

speaker: KING
text_entry: The nature of his great offence is dead,

speaker: KING
text_entry: And deeper than oblivion we do bury

speaker: KING
text_entry: The incensing relics of it: let him approach,

speaker: KING
text_entry: A stranger, no offender; and inform him

speaker: KING
text_entry: So 'tis our will he should.

speaker: Gentleman
text_entry: I shall, my liege.

speaker: Gentleman

speaker: KING
text_entry: For I can guess that by thy honest aid

speaker: KING
text_entry: Thou keep'st a wife herself, thyself a maid.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Of that and all the progress, more or less,

speaker: KING
text_entry: Resolvedly more leisure shall express:

speaker: KING
text_entry: All yet seems well; and if it end so meet,

speaker: KING
text_entry: The bitter past, more welcome is the sweet.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: KING
text_entry: EPILOGUE

speaker: KING
text_entry: The king's a beggar, now the play is done:

speaker: KING
text_entry: All is well ended, if this suit be won,

speaker: KING
text_entry: That you express content; which we will pay,

speaker: KING
text_entry: With strife to please you, day exceeding day:

speaker: KING
text_entry: Ours be your patience then, and yours our parts;

speaker: KING
text_entry: Your gentle hands lend us, and take our hearts.

speaker: KING
text_entry: Exeunt
